4: Online Etymology Dictionary tycoon n. 1857, title given by foreigners to the shogun of Japan (said to have been used by his supporters when addressing foreigners, as an attempt to convey that the shogun was more important than the emperor), from Japanese  taikun  "great lord or prince," from Chinese  tai  "great" +  kiun  "lord." Transferred meaning "important person" is attested from 1861, in reference to U.S. president Abraham Lincoln (in the diary of his secretary, John Hay); specific application to "wealthy and powerful businessman" is post-World War I.

4: Online Etymology Dictionary prowl v. late 14c.,  prollen , "move about in search of something," of unknown origin, with no known cognates. Spelling with  -w-  is from 1500s (compare  bowls ), but pronounced "prôll" till late 18c. Meaning "go stealthily in search of prey" is first recorded 1580s. Related:  Prowled ;  prowling . The noun, in  on the prowl , is attested from 1803.
